organization.$: Department of Materials Science and Technology

head.abstracts: © 2017 Scrivener Publishing LLC.This chapter presents the innovation technique for preparing polymer-encapsulated inorganic renewable nanoparticles (i.e., silica nanoparticles derived from rice husk) by mean of in situ differential microemulsion polymerization which is able to produce particles with an average diameter size less than 50 nm using a much lower amount of surfactant and also providing higher polymer content, compared to microemulsion polymerization. With this technique, silica nanoparticles have been successfully encapsulated by polymers including poly(methyl methacrylate) and polystyrene (PS) with an average diameter size of about 40 and 45 nm, respectively. Moreover, the obtained nanoparticles displayed the core-shell structure with the aggregated silica nanoparticles as a dense core and polymer as a thin covering shell. Either poly(methyl methacrylate)- or PS-encapsulated silica nanoparticles are further used as reinforcing nanofillers in polymer and rubber matrixes including poly(vinyl chloride) and natural rubber. The results revealed that the incorporation of an appropriate amount of nanoparticles can enhance mechanical properties and thermal stability of the nanocomposites resulting in the better dispersion of silica nanoparticles and also stronger interfacial adhesion between nanofillers and polymer matrixes. This is due to the encapsulation of silica nanoparticles by suitable polymers.

organization.$: Department of Materials Science and Technology

coredata.dc:description: This chapter presents the innovation technique for preparing polymer-encapsulated inorganic renewable nanoparticles (i.e., silica nanoparticles derived from rice husk) by mean of in situ differential microemulsion polymerization which is able to produce particles with an average diameter size less than 50 nm using a much lower amount of surfactant and also providing higher polymer content, compared to microemulsion polymerization. With this technique, silica nanoparticles have been successfully encapsulated by polymers including poly(methyl methacrylate) and polystyrene (PS) with an average diameter size of about 40 and 45 nm, respectively. Moreover, the obtained nanoparticles displayed the core-shell structure with the aggregated silica nanoparticles as a dense core and polymer as a thin covering shell. Either poly(methyl methacrylate)- or PS-encapsulated silica nanoparticles are further used as reinforcing nanofillers in polymer and rubber matrixes including poly(vinyl chloride) and natural rubber. The results revealed that the incorporation of an appropriate amount of nanoparticles can enhance mechanical properties and thermal stability of the nanocomposites resulting in the better dispersion of silica nanoparticles and also stronger interfacial adhesion between nanofillers and polymer matrixes. This is due to the encapsulation of silica nanoparticles by suitable polymers.
coredata.dc:title: Encapsulation of inorganic renewable nanofiller
